unit1.title: Unit I - Fundamentals
unit1.description: Basic concepts of pharmacognosy, classifications, and evaluation methods

entries.definition: The study of drugs obtained from natural sources, especially plants, animals, and minerals.
entries.example: Analysis of digitalis leaves for cardiac glycosides is studied in pharmacognosy.

entries.definition: Natural substances used in the unprocessed form or after simple processing, primarily for medicinal purposes.
An ancient Indian system of medicine focused on balancing bodily systems through diet, herbal remedies, and yogic breathing.
entries.example: Use of tulsi leaves to boost immunity.

entries.definition: Traditional Tamil system of medicine using herbs, minerals, and lifestyle practices for health.
entries.example: Use of aloe vera as a cooling agent.

entries.definition: A Greco-Arab system of medicine practiced in India, based on humoral theory.
entries.example: Use of ashwagandha for general wellness.

entries.definition: Grouping crude drugs according to plant part used (root, leaf, bark, etc.).
entries.example: Ginger classified as a rhizome drug.

entries.definition: Arrangement of crude drugs based on their botanical hierarchy (family, genus, species).
entries.example: Azadirachta indica (Neem) belongs to the family Meliaceae.

entries.definition: Categorization of drugs based on their medicinal action.
Organization of drugs by their main chemical constituent.
Nitrogen-containing natural compounds, often with potent medicinal effects.
Molecule where a sugar is bound to a non-sugar substance, often with medicinal value.
Astringent polyphenolic compound found in plants.
Plant glycoside with soap-like properties and medicinal uses.
Assessment of a substance by sensory features (taste, smell, look, touch).
Drug derived from a mineral or inorganic source.
Reducing a crude drug to fine particles.
Addition of inferior or contaminated substances to a drug.
Study of physical, chemical, and biological traits for crude drug identification and quality.
Official publication listing recognized medicinal drugs with standards.
Detailed document describing drugs, their standards, and uses.
Process to ensure consistent quality and purity of drugs.
Ability of a drug to produce desired medical benefit.
entries.example: Efficacy of senna extract as a laxative.

entries.definition: Extracting soluble plant contents by boiling in water.
Steeping plant material in hot or cold water to extract active components.
Soaking plant parts in liquid to extract medicinal contents.
entries.example: Maceration of orange peel in alcohol.

entries.definition: Alcoholic extract of plant or animal material.
Soft, moist mass of plant material applied to skin for healing.
Medicinal product made from plant or plant parts.
Plant used to treat, cure, or prevent disease.
Ratio of toxic dose to effective dose of a drug, indicating safety.
Traditional medicine prepared from natural extracts.
Verification of drug identity to prevent substitution/adulteration.
Compounds produced by plants not required for growth but important medicinally.
Effect of a drug on a living body.
Study of how people use plants in their culture.
Study of plant-derived chemicals and their effects on health.
Plant-based product added to diet for health benefits.
Unwanted material mixed with drugs, lowering quality.
Detection and prevention of adverse drug effects.
Chemical that affects living organisms beneficially.
Essential compound for plant growth and survival.
Physical form in which a drug is produced and taken.
Collection of dried plant specimens for reference and study.
entries.example: A herbarium of medicinal plants in a university.

entries.definition: Measure of active principle extracted from crude drug under specific conditions.
entries.example: Alcohol-soluble extractive value of ashwagandha root.

entries.definition: Undesired material present in a crude drug.
entries.example: Presence of sand in herbal powders.

entries.definition: Amount of residue left after burning crude drug, indicating purity.
Degree to which a crude drug is free from contaminants or adulterants.
Aromatic plant oil that evaporates easily and provides fragrance/flavor.
Agent that soothes inflamed mucous membranes.
Substance that helps expel mucus from respiratory tract.
Substance that tightens tissues, reducing discharge and bleeding.
Substance that relieves gas from stomach/intestines.
Agent that modifies and regulates immune system activity.
Use of bee products in medicine.
The body of collected knowledge about the therapeutic properties of any substance used for healing.
entries.example: Reference to ancient texts on medicinal herbs.

unit2.title: Unit II - Root & Rhizome Drugs
unit2.description: Root drugs, rhizomes, woods, and bark with their medicinal properties

entries.definition: A medicinal plant used as antihypertensive and tranquilizer.
entries.example: Roots are used to treat high blood pressure.

entries.definition: Known as Shatavari, used as a tonic and galactagogue.
entries.example: Used to promote lactation in nursing mothers.

entries.definition: Vetiver root used as a coolant, diuretic, and in perfumes.
entries.example: Added in cooling herbal drinks during summer.

entries.definition: Ginger rhizome used as carminative and antiemetic.
entries.example: Used in ginger tea for nausea relief.

entries.definition: Turmeric rhizome, potent anti-inflammatory and antioxidant.
Calamus rhizome used for digestive and nervous system disorders.
entries.example: Used as a stomachic in herbal syrups.

entries.definition: Sandalwood used for its cooling and antiseptic properties.
entries.example: Paste used for skin rashes and acne.

entries.definition: Neem used for its antibacterial properties and oral health.
entries.example: Neem twigs used for cleaning teeth.

entries.definition: Red sandalwood used for skin diseases and coloring cosmetics.
entries.example: Face packs for cooling and skin lightening.

entries.definition: Arjuna bark used as a potent heart tonic.
Ashoka bark used in gynecological disorders.
entries.example: Ashoka bark extract for menstrual health.

entries.definition: Cinnamon bark used as a flavoring and digestive aid.
entries.example: Added to sweets for taste and digestive support.

entries.definition: Drugs derived from the roots of plants, usually containing potent bioactive compounds.
Medicinal substances obtained from plant rhizomes (underground stems).
Drugs in which the main therapeutic agents are found in the heartwood.
Medicines obtained from the bark of trees or shrubs, often rich in tannins and alkaloids.
Substance that increases breast milk production.
Drug used to reduce tension or anxiety.
Prevents the growth of disease-causing organisms.
A substance that helps expel mucus from the airways.
Medication used for female reproductive health.
Herb used for taste and sometimes with medicinal value.
Plant part used in fragrance production.
Substance inhibiting oxidation and combating free radicals.
Natural substance helping the body adapt to stress.
Plant-based substance used to soothe skin.
Plant part used for cleaning teeth.
Used to clean or treat the mouth.
Causes tightening of tissues; reduces secretions.
Ingredient for preparation of cooling beverages.
Plant part with beneficial secondary compounds.
Used in Ayurveda for health and healing.
entries.example: Arjuna bark in cardiac ayurvedic medicines.

entries.definition: Used in herbal oils and shampoos.
Addresses reproductive system disorders in women.
Root used in folk or traditional healing practices.

unit3.title: Unit III - Aerial Parts
unit3.description: Leaves, flowers, fruits, seeds, and entire plants with medicinal uses

entries.definition: Used for treating burns, wounds, and skin infections.
entries.example: Aloe vera gel applied topically for sunburn relief.

entries.definition: Used as an expectorant and for respiratory ailments.
entries.example: Leaves boiled to make a cough syrup.

entries.definition: Used as anti-stress, antibacterial and immune booster.
entries.example: Tulsi tea consumed for cold relief.

entries.definition: Used as antiseptic, analgesic, and anti-inflammatory.
Used as an antioxidant and mood enhancer.
entries.example: Saffron used as a spice and in medicines for depression.

entries.definition: Used for hair growth and as an astringent.
entries.example: Hibiscus oil used for hair care.

entries.definition: Used as digestive aid and carminative.
entries.example: Coriander seeds used in cooking and digestion.

entries.definition: Used as a rich vitamin C source and antioxidant.
entries.example: Amla fruit consumed for immunity improvement.

entries.definition: Used as stimulant, carminative and antibacterial.
entries.example: Black pepper used in spice blends and digestion.

entries.definition: Used as carminative and digestive stimulant.
entries.example: Cardamom seeds used in teas and digestive preparations.

entries.definition: Used as galactagogue and digestive aid.
entries.example: Fenugreek seeds consumed by lactating mothers.

entries.definition: Used as laxative and digestive tonic.
entries.example: Haritaki fruit used in Ayurvedic detox.

entries.definition: Used for liver protection and antiviral purposes.
Used to enhance memory and cognitive function.
entries.example: Brahmi extract used in brain supplements.

entries.definition: Used for diabetes and cancer treatment.
entries.example: Vincristine from plant used in chemotherapy.
Used in culinary and medicinal preparations.
Combined with turmeric for better absorption.

entries.definition: Used on burns and wounds for healing.
Analgesic and antiseptic for dental pain.
entries.example: Oil of cloves used in dentistry.

entries.definition: Soothes burns and promotes skin repair.
Enhances breast milk production in nursing mothers.
entries.example: Fenugreek tea consumed daily by lactating women.

entries.definition: Complete body cleansing and digestive system reset.
entries.example: Haritaki powder mixed in warm water for detoxification.

unit4.title: Unit IV - Poisonous Plants
unit4.description: Plant poisons, toxic effects, and treatment methods

entries.definition: Nitrogenous organic compounds toxic to humans.
Natural glycoside products with toxic aglycone part.
Potent nerve poison from aconitine alkaloid.
From fish liver, vitamin D source.

unit5.title: Unit V - Herbal Preparations
unit5.description: Formulations and remedies for common diseases

entries.definition: Herbal cleansing mixture for body care.
Natural hair cleanser made from plants.
Distilled extract of rose petals used as toner.
Sweet herbal extraction in liquid form.
Boiling herbs in water for medicine.
Extract of herbs in oil for therapy.
Infusion of herbs for health drink.
Medicated herbal oil for hair growth.
Decoction of neem leaves reduces fever.
Ginger aids digestion and reduces bloating.
Amla juice for preventing frequent cold.
Aloe vera juice reduces fever inflammation.
Sandalwood paste on forehead reduces temperature.
Oil with medicinal properties for pain.
